awd_titl_txt: RoL: Conference: DESYN-C3: An International Conference on Engineering Synthetic Cells and Organelles
awd_abstract_narration:
The International Conference on Engineering Synthetic Cells and Organelles will be held near Albuquerque, New Mexico during the summer of 2019. The conference focuses on synthetic biology, establishes the state-of-the-art of synthetic cell technology, and identifies grand challenges and opportunities for future work in this field. It features world leaders in synthetic cell technology from premier US and international universities and national laboratories. The meeting addresses the mission of NSF, which has been increasingly committed to integrating the engineering sciences with the life sciences, encouraging research and development in multidisciplinary areas, educating the next generation of young scientists, and supporting cutting edge science to answer current and future challenges as well as making sure US-based scientists are globally engaged. 

Topics of the conference will focus on development of foundational technologies for creating synthetic cells. The conference will hold sessions on five topics over 2.5 days in a single-track format. The topics will be (1) strategies to create synthetic cells and organelles; (2) spatial and temporal organization of synthetic cytoplasmic structures; (3) sensing, signaling, and circuits; (4) molecular machines, mechanics, and motility; and (5) implications of synthetic cell technology. The conference proceedings, and a companion technology roadmap, will be published subsequent to the conference.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The synthesis and fabrication of microscopic particles with cell-like attributes and functions is a current grand challenge in synthetic biology and biomaterials being pursued by leading research institutions around the world. This project aimed to spur new, global, interdisciplinary collaborations and to create a new international venue for the burgeoning field of research into synthetic cells and organelles. To this end, the International Conference on Engineering Synthetic Cells and Organelles was inaugurated. Originally planned as an in-person conference to be held in May 2020, by necessity of the COVID-19 pandemic this Conference was ultimately held virtually over the period of May 2020 ? May 2021. The virtual format, for which no registration fee was imposed, greatly increased the number and diversity of attendees that could participate. Leading researchers in synthetic cell technology presented their latest results as well as tutorials for newcomers to the field. A juried virtual poster session allowed wide participation of researchers. Videos of most of the presentations remain available on the internet. With these activities, the project provided educational opportunities to hundreds of students and it laid the groundwork for a long-term international forum for scientific exchange in the field of synthetic cells and organelles.

The intellectual merit of this project includes the establishment of a productive and sustainable collaboration on information exchange and dissemination among leading researchers in the field, including those from three major multi-institutional consortia, the US-based Build-A-Cell Research Collaboration Network, the Max Planck School Matter to Life (Germany), and the Building a Synthetic Cell (BaSyC) Consortium (Netherlands).  The broader impact of the project includes new and accessible educational and career development opportunities available to students and young researchers from a broad spectrum of backgrounds. An open-access, featured article that presents these aspects of intellectual merit and broader impacts of the project was published in the journal eLife.

 


Last Modified: 01/07/2022
Modified by: Gabriel P Lopez
